title: Cat. 129  Beaker, 3rd/4th century A.D.
publication_title: Roman Art at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Beaker  
3rd/4th century A.D.  
Roman  
Glass, mold-blown; h. 12.7 cm (5 in.); diam. 8.6 cm (3 3/8 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Theodore W. and Frances S. Robinson, 1946.1050

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">Transparent light-yellow-green glass. Pattern-molded, blown, trail decorated, and tooled. A thickened, rounded rim flares out from a sharply tapering, straight-sided vessel wall attached to a thickened, flattened base. There is a pontil mark on the underside. The body is spirally ribbed; about a quarter of the way down the vessel wall, a single thick horizontal trail defines the start of the spiral decoration below it. For a zoomable image, see fig. 129.1.

The beaker is intact, with an overall light-brown incrustation and thin, milky weathering product with some patches of iridescence.

This is an unusual variation on a form that appears with a variety of base types throughout the Roman world, in all periods. The applied trail on a pattern-molded body suggests a later date for the beaker.

There are two related beakers in the Princeton University Art Museum. One is comparable to this vessel but with more characteristic sets of wheel-cut decoration on the body; the other one is plain and has a similar profile. There is a similar form in the Middle Eastern Culture Center, Tokyo, with the same tooled foot but without applied decoration. A beaker said to have been in a Jerusalem private collection, on the American market, and another, formerly in the Erwin Oppenländer collection in Waiblingen, near Stuttgart, are two more variations, the Oppenländer beaker being more flared and said to be from the Black Sea region and found at Olbia.  
Sidney Goldstein

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">Isings, Roman Glass from Dated Finds, p. 48, form 34.

See Antonaras, Fire and Sand, pp. 129–30, nos. 173 and 174, which is compared to Isings form 109c, a later vessel type that is found in Frankish tomb groups; Isings, Roman Glass from Dated Finds, pp. 136–37.

Idemitsu Museum of Arts, Treasures of the Orient, pp. 138, 260, no. 169.

Fortuna Fine Arts, Solid Liquid, p. 69, no. 120, is probably later than its first-century-A.D. attribution.

Saldern et al., Gläser der Antike, pp. 258–59, no. 757, color illus.; p. 245, a beaker on a solid pad base and no decoration, 4th/5th century A.D.

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 129 Beaker, 3rd/4th century A.D.

fig. 129.1 Beaker (3rd/4th century A.D.). The Art Institute of Chicago, 1946.1050. Zoomable image.

</section>
